<p>U.S. lawmakers are coming for the free and open internet in the name of "child safety," and now they're even saying the quiet part out loud.</p><p>In recent years, numerous bills have cropped up to chip away at <a href="https://mashable.com/category/privacy" target="_self"><u>internet privacy</u></a> and security. To name a few: <a href="https://www.vox.com/culture/2018/4/13/17172762/fosta-sesta-backpage-230-internet-freedom" target="_blank" title="(opens in a new window)"><u>FOSTA-SESTA</u></a>, passed in 2018, which weakened <a href="https://mashable.com/article/republicans-big-tech-section-230-censorship" target="_self"><u>Section 230</u></a> of the 1996 Communications Decency Act so that websites and social platforms were liable for "sexual solicitation" posts; the <a href="https://mashable.com/article/earn-it-act-threatens-privacy-encryption-section-230" target="_self"><u>EARN IT Act</u></a>, introduced in 2020 and <a href="https://www.judiciary.senate.gov/press/rep/releases/graham-blumenthal-reintroduce-earn-it-act" target="_blank" title="(opens in a new window)"><u>reintroduced in 2022</u></a>, which would further weaken Section 230; <a href="https://mashable.com/article/what-are-age-verification-bills-porn-louisiana-utah" target="_self"><u>age-verification bills</u></a>, passed in Louisiana and elsewhere, which require porn site visitors to show ID; and the Kids Online Safety Act, also known as <a href="https://www.blackburn.senate.gov/2023/5/blackburn-blumenthal-introduce-bipartisan-kids-online-safety-act" target="_blank" title="(opens in a new window)"><u>KOSA, which was introduced in 2022</u></a> and reintroduced this year.</p><div class="mx-auto mt-8 w-full max-w-3xl font-sans text-lg leading-normal md:text-xl md:leading-7">
<span class="font-bold text-primary-400">SEE ALSO:</span>
<a href="https://mashable.com/article/what-are-age-verification-bills-porn-louisiana-utah" class="text-secondary-300">
Why age-verification bills for porn sites won't work
<svg class="inline-block ml-1 w-4 h-4 font-normal fill-current"><use href="/images/icons/spritemap.svg#sprite-arrow-right-thin"></use></svg>
</a>
</div>
<p>At a glance, these bills seem positive. We want everyone, especially children, to be protected and safe online; that's why KOSA has <a href="https://www.commerce.senate.gov/2023/7/senate-commerce-committee-approves-11-bills-including-bipartisan-children-s-online-privacy-legislation" target="_blank" title="(opens in a new window)"><u>bipartisan support</u></a>, including an <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/2023/07/26/pass-it-pass-it-pass-it-pass-it-pass-it-the-president-says-about-a-bill-the-gop-says-will-be-useful-to-silence-lgbtq-voices/" target="_blank" title="(opens in a new window)"><u>endorsement from President Joe Biden</u></a>. But KOSA wouldn't actually protect children. It'd make the internet less private, and thus less safe, for everyone. What's more is that conservatives would use it to target LGBTQ content. </p><p>In <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jg21OdmUj1g" target="_blank" title="(opens in a new window)">an interview</a> with conservative Christian organization Family Policy Alliance earlier this year that was uploaded to YouTube over Labor Day weekend, Republican Sen. Marsha Blackburn — the lead co-sponsor for KOSA — said that "protecting minor children from the transgender [sic] in this culture and that influence" should be a top issue for conservatives now. </p><div class="mx-auto mt-8 w-full max-w-4xl">

<p>Blackburn then mentions KOSA, saying that it would put a duty of care on social media platforms. This means that platforms would be responsible to "prevent and mitigate harms to minors" including content promoting "self-harm, suicide, eating disorders, substance abuse, and sexual exploitation" according to Blackburn's and co-sponsor Democratic Sen. Richard Blumenthal's <a href="https://www.blumenthal.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/kids_online_safety_act_-_one_pager.pdf" target="_blank" title="(opens in a new window)"><u>KOSA one-pager</u></a>. The Federal Trade Commission and individual state attorneys general would enforce this, as stated in the <a href="https://www.blackburn.senate.gov/services/files/D89FC49B-0714-4124-B8B1-4F35A85F5E02" target="_blank" title="(opens in a new window)"><u>full KOSA bill</u></a>.</p><p>Blackburn's team insists that protecting children from transgender culture and influence and KOSA are two separate points. Blackburn's legislative director Jamie Susskind replied to coverage of the interview, tweeting, "This is false. These are two separate issues being taken out of context. KOSA will not — nor was it designed to — target or censor any individual or community."</p><blockquote class="twitter-tweet">
<a class="text-gray-600" href="https://twitter.com/butmostlyjamie/status/1698505755471556904" target="_blank" rel="noopener" title="(opens in a new window)">
Tweet may have been deleted
</a>
</blockquote>
<p>While KOSA may not explicitly go after LGBTQ content, that could very well be the result. "Even without targeted measures, the Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA) could have severely detrimental consequences for LGBTQ+ online content," wrote trans reporter and advocate Erin Reed about <a href="https://www.erininthemorning.com/p/senator-admits-kids-online-safety" target="_blank" title="(opens in a new window)"><u>Blackburn's comments</u></a>, citing data from GLAAD about how <a href="https://glaad.org/smsi/lgbtq-social-media-safety-program/" target="_blank" title="(opens in a new window)"><u>LGBTQ content is disproportionately blocked</u></a> or shadowbanned by social media platforms already. </p><p>Indeed, there is a <a href="https://www.brennancenter.org/our-work/research-reports/double-standards-social-media-content-moderation" target="_blank" title="(opens in a new window)"><u>double standard on social platforms</u></a>: Content from marginalized groups faces increased scrutiny from platforms, and the platforms don't protect them against harassment. <a href="https://mashable.com/article/instagram-shadowbanning-lgbtq-sex-educator-accounts" target="_self"><u>LGBTQ Instagram users</u></a>, for instance, told Mashable they're often shadowbanned and blocked when posting non-nude, non-sexual content. </p><h2>KOSA could massively impact everyone's online rights</h2><p>In addition to silencing LGBTQ people, KOSA can have other detrimental ramifications. Activism director of the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) Jason Kelley wrote that <a href="https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/05/kids-online-safety-act-still-huge-danger-our-rights-online" target="_blank" title="(opens in a new window)"><u>KOSA is a danger to our online rights</u></a> in several ways. For one, attorneys general would have the power to block content if they deem it dangerous for young people — be it about anything from trans healthcare to substance use to gun ownership. </p><p>For another, KOSA would likely drive websites to use age verification to meet the requirements of the legislation. It would "require, essentially, websites to not show certain types of content to young people," said Kelley in a March interview with Mashable. "But of course, then the question is, how do they know who is a young person?" </p><div class="mx-auto mt-8 w-full max-w-3xl font-sans text-lg leading-normal md:text-xl md:leading-7">
<span class="font-bold text-primary-400">SEE ALSO:</span>
<a href="https://mashable.com/uk/roundup/best-vpn-for-porn-uk" class="text-secondary-300">

<svg class="inline-block ml-1 w-4 h-4 font-normal fill-current"><use href="/images/icons/spritemap.svg#sprite-arrow-right-thin"></use></svg>
</a>
</div>
<p>As Mashable reported on specified "age-verification bills," requiring <a href="https://mashable.com/article/what-are-age-verification-bills-porn-louisiana-utah" target="_self"><u>age verification doesn't work</u></a>. As users would be obligated to share personal, identifying information, there'd be a heightened privacy risk; <a href="https://www.pcmag.com/opinions/louisianas-new-porn-law-is-a-privacy-time-bomb" target="_blank" title="(opens in a new window)"><u>identity theft could increase</u></a>, for instance. </p><p>"There's this giant censorship machine that also is privacy invasive," Kelley told Mashable. </p><p>Further, age-verification systems could be bypassed with software like VPNs, rendering them useless for their proposed purpose.</p><p>How do we protect kids online? <a href="https://mashable.com/article/what-are-age-verification-bills-porn-louisiana-utah" target="_self"><u>Device-level filters</u></a>, which block all websites that are "restricted to adults" are a start. Furthermore, talking with your <a href="https://mashable.com/feature/how-to-master-internet-safety-for-kids" target="_self"><u>children about online safety</u></a> is imperative. On the legislative level, Kelley is a proponent of stronger, more comprehensive privacy laws and increased competition.</p><p>"Part of the problem is we are focusing on restriction instead of other kinds of beneficial aspects of the web that could make things better for everyone," he said. "People don't want their data to be collected, people want to have control over [their data]...The reason that these websites don't exist is that there are no comprehensive privacy laws." </p><p>With increased competition, say there was a YouTube competitor that had more features and allowed you to make decisions about how the algorithms work — users would like that, and YouTube would be forced to keep up.</p><p>Sen. Richard Blumenthal, who co-sponsored the legislation, told Mashable in a statement:</p><blockquote><p>The Kids Online Safety Act does not target or censor anyone, including members of the LGBTQ community. The Kids Online Safety Act was specifically drafted to narrowly target the real, deadly harms that children face online — eating disorders, suicide, and illicit drugs. Striking the right balance between supporting safe online spaces and protecting against toxic content targeting LGBTQ youth is very important to us, which is why my staff and I had extensive and collaborative conversations with stakeholders, including LGBTQ groups, to further clarify the legislative text so that it better reflects the intent of the bill. Those changes are reflected in the reintroduced version of the bill. We will always have an open door to communities and stakeholders who share our common goal of protecting kids from real harms online — and who want to hold Big Tech accountable.</p></blockquote><p class="mx-auto">

readabilityObject.content:
KOSA would target LGBTQ online content, and make the internet less private. Credit: Bob Al-Greene / Mashable

U.S. lawmakers are coming for the free and open internet in the name of "child safety," and now they're even saying the quiet part out loud.

In recent years, numerous bills have cropped up to chip away at internet privacy and security. To name a few: FOSTA-SESTA, passed in 2018, which weakened Section 230 of the 1996 Communications Decency Act so that websites and social platforms were liable for "sexual solicitation" posts; the EARN IT Act, introduced in 2020 and reintroduced in 2022, which would further weaken Section 230; age-verification bills, passed in Louisiana and elsewhere, which require porn site visitors to show ID; and the Kids Online Safety Act, also known as KOSA, which was introduced in 2022 and reintroduced this year.

At a glance, these bills seem positive. We want everyone, especially children, to be protected and safe online; that's why KOSA has bipartisan support, including an endorsement from President Joe Biden. But KOSA wouldn't actually protect children. It'd make the internet less private, and thus less safe, for everyone. What's more is that conservatives would use it to target LGBTQ content. 

In an interview with conservative Christian organization Family Policy Alliance earlier this year that was uploaded to YouTube over Labor Day weekend, Republican Sen. Marsha Blackburn the lead co-sponsor for KOSA said that "protecting minor children from the transgender [sic] in this culture and that influence" should be a top issue for conservatives now.

Blackburn then mentions KOSA, saying that it would put a duty of care on social media platforms. This means that platforms would be responsible to "prevent and mitigate harms to minors" including content promoting "self-harm, suicide, eating disorders, substance abuse, and sexual exploitation" according to Blackburn's and co-sponsor Democratic Sen. Richard Blumenthal's KOSA one-pager. The Federal Trade Commission and individual state attorneys general would enforce this, as stated in the full KOSA bill.

Blackburn's team insists that protecting children from transgender culture and influence and KOSA are two separate points. Blackburn's legislative director Jamie Susskind replied to coverage of the interview, tweeting, "This is false. These are two separate issues being taken out of context. KOSA will not nor was it designed to target or censor any individual or community."

Tweet may have been deleted

While KOSA may not explicitly go after LGBTQ content, that could very well be the result. "Even without targeted measures, the Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA) could have severely detrimental consequences for LGBTQ+ online content," wrote trans reporter and advocate Erin Reed about Blackburn's comments, citing data from GLAAD about how LGBTQ content is disproportionately blocked or shadowbanned by social media platforms already. 

Indeed, there is a double standard on social platforms: Content from marginalized groups faces increased scrutiny from platforms, and the platforms don't protect them against harassment. LGBTQ Instagram users, for instance, told Mashable they're often shadowbanned and blocked when posting non-nude, non-sexual content. 

KOSA could massively impact everyone's online rights

In addition to silencing LGBTQ people, KOSA can have other detrimental ramifications. Activism director of the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) Jason Kelley wrote that KOSA is a danger to our online rights in several ways. For one, attorneys general would have the power to block content if they deem it dangerous for young people be it about anything from trans healthcare to substance use to gun ownership. 

For another, KOSA would likely drive websites to use age verification to meet the requirements of the legislation. It would "require, essentially, websites to not show certain types of content to young people," said Kelley in a March interview with Mashable. "But of course, then the question is, how do they know who is a young person?"

As Mashable reported on specified "age-verification bills," requiring age verification doesn't work. As users would be obligated to share personal, identifying information, there'd be a heightened privacy risk; identity theft could increase, for instance. 

"There's this giant censorship machine that also is privacy invasive," Kelley told Mashable. 

Further, age-verification systems could be bypassed with software like VPNs, rendering them useless for their proposed purpose.

How do we protect kids online? Device-level filters, which block all websites that are "restricted to adults" are a start. Furthermore, talking with your children about online safety is imperative. On the legislative level, Kelley is a proponent of stronger, more comprehensive privacy laws and increased competition.

"Part of the problem is we are focusing on restriction instead of other kinds of beneficial aspects of the web that could make things better for everyone," he said. "People don't want their data to be collected, people want to have control over [their data]...The reason that these websites don't exist is that there are no comprehensive privacy laws." 

With increased competition, say there was a YouTube competitor that had more features and allowed you to make decisions about how the algorithms work users would like that, and YouTube would be forced to keep up.

Sen. Richard Blumenthal, who co-sponsored the legislation, told Mashable in a statement:

The Kids Online Safety Act does not target or censor anyone, including members of the LGBTQ community. The Kids Online Safety Act was specifically drafted to narrowly target the real, deadly harms that children face online eating disorders, suicide, and illicit drugs. Striking the right balance between supporting safe online spaces and protecting against toxic content targeting LGBTQ youth is very important to us, which is why my staff and I had extensive and collaborative conversations with stakeholders, including LGBTQ groups, to further clarify the legislative text so that it better reflects the intent of the bill. Those changes are reflected in the reintroduced version of the bill. We will always have an open door to communities and stakeholders who share our common goal of protecting kids from real harms online and who want to hold Big Tech accountable.

UPDATE: Sep. 5, 2023, 11:03 a.m. EDT This article has been updated to correct when the Sen. Blackburn interview took place, add a statement from Blackburn's legislative director, and clarify that age verification is likely to be a ripple effect of the legislation. The article was then subsequently updated with a statement from Sen. Blumenthal.

Anna Iovine is the sex and relationships reporter at Mashable, where she covers topics ranging from dating apps to pelvic pain. Previously, she was a social editor at VICE and freelanced for publications such as Slate and the Columbia Journalism Review. Follow her on Twitter @annaroseiovine.
